children.subject: Hi, OP. I am in the exact same boat as you do. And my choice is to drop the B-/C+ class and keep the test graded. Hope this helps.
Hey Atom, due to other circumstances, I am unable to drop the course. I only have the choices I mentioned above.
My advice would be all graded. Regardless of whether you take your classes all graded vs some graded, they won't look at your grades too heavily, so I wouldn't worry too much about it
Due to other unfortunate circumstances (there are a whole lot of them at play here haha), I cannot drop the course either.
you can also considering dropping that class entirely?

Thanks for your input. What do you think would be a good enough grade to be worth keeping given the circumstances surrounding this semester? I'm not sure what I'll end up getting in this class because we still have a fairly large amount of the grade remaining to be handed out, but I don't feel confident of my chances of getting higher than a B-.
It’s hard to say, I would say a B+ maybe? But then again I am not in any admission committee so don’t just take my word for it.
That's funny because that's what I was thinking would be a good threshold as well. Not sure if I'll be able to pull it off, but I guess I'll give it a shot.
Yeah, I think you could and maybe should still work hard in the class if it’s possible since you can still change grade option in the last minute

This is a tricky question to answer since none of us here is in some admission committee for grad school so there may be no right answer.
Personally I think one B-/C won’t matter that much as long as your general grade pattern is positive or people can see you are progressing instead of just, you know, acing all the lower div and struggling with all the upper div.
But in this case since you have an option to PNP it, I would probably go for PNP. Think about it this way. Since you are bound to have a C/B-, what looks worse on your transcript? A P that doesn’t affect your GPA and may or may not negatively affect the impression of your transcript. Or you can have a C that’s definitely gonna lower the GPA and definitely gonna have negative impact. To put it simple, in the worst case scenario, a P is as bad as a C, but it can’t get any worse than a C, only slightly better.
Of course if you can go for a better grade you should definitely try that as your priority. But if you are definitely gonna get a C I would say just PNP it.

history.content:
I'm a junior enrolled in 3 CS upper div courses right now, and due to some unfortunate circumstances I'm probably going to end up with a B- or worse in one of the courses. I'm on track for solid As in the other 2 courses. I aim to apply to Masters programs at most other good CS schools next academic year, as well as the MEng program at Berkeley, but not the 5th year EECS Masters at Berkeley because that's too competitive for me to get into. 

I was wondering whether I should P/NP all 3 courses, take all 3 courses for a letter grade, or take 1 P/NP and the other 2 graded. I have read on here that some professors advise against the last option for grad school. However, I'm not sure if it will also be looked down upon for Masters/MEng programs? Is there someone who has actual eyes and ears in the pertinent admissions' process that I could contact regarding this?

Also for reference, my GPA if I were to take 2 graded and 1 P/NP would be about 3.8, if I were to take all 3 graded my GPA would tank to < 3.75, and taking all 3 P/NP would lead to something in between.
history.subject: P/NP vs B-/C+ for Masters?
